title: Russia Issues A Spine-Chilling Threat To Western Leaders
cleaned_text:
Russia on Thursday warned the United States and NATO they would suffer “catastrophic repercussions” if they continued to support the war in Ukraine.

“The U.S. and NATO policies targeted at further inflaming the crisis in and surrounding Ukraine,” according to Sergei Ryabkov, deputy foreign minister of Russia, is currently “the most severe strategic threat.”

“Their increasing involvement in an armed conflict is dangerous because it raises the possibility of a direct military conflict between nuclear powers with fatal repercussions.”

AFP informs In contrast to the Western diplomats who had gathered for a nearby picture opportunity standing in front of a mural painted inside the yellow and blue of the Ukrainian flag during his planned speaking time, Russia’s diplomatic representative spoke in front of a mostly empty chamber.

“We regard this as an extraordinary display of solidarity with the Ukrainian individuals fighting an unwarranted and unjustified Russia’s assault,” Ukraine’s envoy Yevheniia Filipenko told the site.

“We are here to support our Ukrainian colleague until Russia removes its tanks from the field of Ukraine,” according to reports from British ambassador Simon Manley.

Russia has threatened to take action just days after NATO granted Ukraine’s bid for membership as soon as possible, according to Breitbart News.

During a visit to Helsinki, the capital of Finland, Stoltenberg said to reporters, “NATO allies have decided that Ukraine will become an official member of our alliance, yet at the same time this represents a long-term perspective.”

The notion that membership is just a step away was reiterated in Kiev by Stoltenberg’s speech.

In a video message delivered on Thursday morning, U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken emphasized the importance of extending a high-level war crimes probe into Moscow’s operations against its neighbor, a so-called Commission of Investigation, into Russia’s conduct in Ukraine.

“The COI should continue to document such atrocities as long as Russia continues to carry out its war, offering an impartial record of what’s happening and a foundation for international and national attempts to hold criminals accountable,” he said.

“Governments that carry out crimes overseas are also likely to violate human rights at home, and Russia is doing just that.”
